thread.title: Incumbents have tough fights ahead as Dallas City Council campaign season officially begins | Dallas City Hall | Dallas News
thread.title_full: Incumbents have tough fights ahead as Dallas City Council campaign season officially begins | Dallas City Hall | Dallas News

title: Incumbents have tough fights ahead as Dallas City Council campaign season officially begins | Dallas City Hall | Dallas News

organizations.name: philip kingston in city council district

text:
Get Unlimited Digital Access Your first month is less than a dollar. $0.99 for first 4 weeks Subscribe Now 
Come June, the Dallas City Council could have a whole new look that might feature some familiar faces. Or not. 
While city officials were still sifting through paperwork late Friday, at least 10 of the 14 council races in the May 6 election will be contested. Two Dallas ISD seats will also feature multiple candidates on the ballot. 
Every Dallas council member south of the Trinity River has at least one opponent. And some of the races could turn out to be slugfests. 
Former longtime City Council members Tennell Atkins and Dwaine Caraway are back again after term limits forced them to step aside in 2015. Caraway will have a one-on-one showdown with Carolyn King Arnold, who he helped get elected. A proposed deck park spanning Interstate 35 near the Dallas Zoo will be a hot-button issue in that race. Atkins, meanwhile, will run in a crowded field that includes Deputy Mayor Pro Tem Erik Wilson and 2015 third-place finisher Gail Terrell. 
In southwestern Dallas, former teacher Joe Tave will get a rematch against council member Casey Thomas after losing by less than 200 votes in the 2015 runoff. 
In Pleasant Grove, council member Rickey Callahan will seek a third term against lawyer Dominique Torres, who lists prominent Friendship-West Baptist Church's senior pastor Frederick Haynes as her treasurer. 
And in South Dallas, Tiffinni Young has five challengers, including her 2015 opponent Kevin Felder and neighborhood activist Tammy Johnston. The campaign will likely focus on the fate of Fair Park and quality of life issues. Dallas council member Tiffinni Young is reflected in a logo of the City of Dallas in a elevator at Dallas City Hall Thursday August 6, 2015. Her district is City Council District 7. (Ron Baselice/The Dallas Morning News) Kevin Felder, a candidate for Dallas City Council District 7. Courtesy Panelists Joe Tave (right) and John H. Martinez listen during "Conversations About RACE" Saturday, February 22, 2014 at Dallas City Hall. Tave is running for City Council District 8 against Casey Thomas. (G.J. McCarthy/The Dallas Morning News) Casey Thomas, Dallas City Councilman for District 3, speaks during the Commemorative Air Force Wings Over Dallas WWII Airshow Friday, October 28, 2016 in Dallas. Thomas is facing Joe Tave in his bid for a second term. (G.J. McCarthy/The Dallas Morning News) City Council member Erik Wilson speaks during the Board of Trustees meeting at Dallas Police and Fire Pension System in Dallas, Thursday, Oct. 13, 2016. Wilson is hoping to win a second term against a crowded field. (Jae S. Lee/The Dallas Morning News) Former Dallas City Council member Tennell Atkins stands in the new Save-A-Lot grocery store at 3450 Simpson Stuart Road. Atkins is trying to win back his seat after he had to step aside due to term limits. (Tristan Hallman/Staff) City Council Member Carolyn King Arnold speaks at the Dallas Police Department hosted community meeting at Cedar Crest Cathedral in Dallas, Texas, on Tuesday, January 31, 2017. Arnold is facing former City Council member Dwaine Caraway in her re-election bid. (Allison Slomowitz/ Special Contributor) Dwaine Caraway, the former acting mayor and longtime city council member announces that he is running for his old council seat in the lobby of City Hall in Dallas Wednesday, Feb. 1, 2017. (Guy Reynolds/The Dallas Morning News) Staff Photographer Matt Wood, who is running against Philip Kingston in City Council District 14. City Council member Philip T. Kingston is seen during the Board of Trustees meeting at Dallas Police and Fire Pension System in Dallas, Thursday, Oct. 13, 2016. Kingston will face Kim Welch and Matt Wood in his re-election campaign. (Jae S. Lee/The Dallas Morning News) Staff Photographer Dallas City Councilmember Lee M. Kleinman takes part in the council meeting on Tuesday, November 10, 2015 at Dallas City Hall. Kleinman is running for a third term against real estate blogger Candy Evans, his neighbor. (David Woo/The Dallas Morning News) Bernadette Schaeffler, Candy Evans at Rockitecture 2014 at the Room on Main benefiting the Dallas Center for Architecture, May 1, 2014. Evans is trying to unseat Lee Kleinman in his north Dallas district (Photograph by Bruno/Special Contributor) Monica Alonzo, who is Dallas mayor pro tem and district 6 councilwoman, speaks during a ceremony at El Centro College to heal and reflect on the July 7th shooting that recently occurred on and near the campus in down Dallas Wednesday July 27, 2016. Alonzo is seeking a fourth term in a crowded field of candidates in her West Dallas district. (Andy Jacobsohn/The Dallas Morning News) Campaign fundraising manager Michelle Love (left), party guest Ellen Touchstone and Omar Narvaez, president of the Stonewall Democrats of Dallas, sit and wait for election results during Domingo Garcia's watch party for the Democratic primary in the 33rd Congressional District on May 29, 2012. Narvaez is running for City Council district 6 against incumbent Monica Alonzo and other challengers (Jeff Lautenberger/The Dallas Morning News). Gil Cerda, candidate for city council District 6, at his small neighborhood store, Tuesday morning, Feb. 14, 2017 in Arlington. (Ben Torres/Special Contributor) In this 2008 photo, Tony Carrillo stands in his driveway on Parvia Street in La Bajada awaiting a throw from his son, Marcos, 14, across the street Thursday, May 16, 2008 in Dallas. Carrillo is running for City Council in West Dallas. Gail Terrell is running for City Council in southeastern Dallas against former City Council member Tennell Atkins and incumbent council member Erik Wilson. 
In North Dallas, incumbent Lee Kleinman will square off against his neighbor, real estate blogger Candy Evans. While the Dallas Police Association and Dallas Fire Fighters Association has yet to endorse Evans, they've made clear they want Kleinman out. 
Mayor Pro Tem Monica Alonzo will have to face a crowded field of contenders in her West Dallas district, where gentrification concerns are on voters' minds. Dallas County Schools board member Omar Narvaez, who has the support of council member Philip Kingston, headlines the field of candidates. 
But Kingston, who is seeking a third term and is known as an indefatigable campaigner, could be preoccupied in his own backyard. On Friday, he drew a surprise serious challenger: Matthew Wood, a lawyer and East Dallas neighborhood advocate who headed the city's bid for the 2024 Summer Olympics. 
Wood already has the endorsements of former Mayor Ron Kirk, lawyer Bobby Abtahi, activists Suzanne Smith and Mita Havlick. Abtahi lost a hard-fought runoff to Kingston in 2013, and Smith had Kingston's endorsement in her campaign for Dallas ISD trustee last year. 
Dustin Marshall, the CEO of Hazel's Hot Shot who defeated Havlick and Smith in the Dallas ISD race, is also up for re-election on the Dallas ISD board of trustees. 
Marshall, 39, will face Richard Young, 37, a fourth-grade writing teacher at Dallas Gateway Charter School, and physician assistant Lori Kirkpatrick, 51. Young unsuccessfully ran for the Midlothian ISD board of trustees in 2013. 
District 6 trustee Joyce Foreman, 68, has one opponent in the May election: author and nonprofit founder Phelesha Hamilton, 31. 
Staff writer Corbett Smith contributed to this report. Who is on the ballot? Dallas City Council
